{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3418126,"name":"Nadav Asor","username":"NadavA","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/f1d935/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-26T14:05:10.265Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone, Our team’s CAD subteam is currently searching for a reliable PDM system to use with SolidWorks (with SLDPRT Files (.sldprt) and SLDASM Files (.sldasm))
We’d love to hear about the PDM platform your team uses and how it’s been working for you. Any recommendations or insights would be greatly appreciated!

Here are some recent threads that you may want to look at (this is from a quick search. There are definitely more)

Help me Find a Good PDM CAD
I Need A Good PDM Software That Works Well With Solidworks Files. Does Anyone have one?
PDM help! Technical
We were trying 3D experience all morning but we didn´t like the interface and it consumes a lot of resources of the computer. What solution are you using instead of Grabcad? We considering to try Google Drive, but we know it is not the most optmized option.
Introducing CacheCAD CAD
I’m very excited to introduce CacheCAD to the FRC community. CacheCAD is a file management interface for Google Drive developed with Team 8096, Cache Money. Unlike the Google Drive app, CacheCAD lets you selectively sync your files with a simple interface. It aims to be a true GrabCAD replacement. Google Drive is ideal because all user setup, permissions, and sharing settings are handled through the Google web interface which many teams are familiar with and already using. Because all data is …

Highly recommend CacheCAD. It is what we use on 67 and love it. It is developed and run by @Mike_Schreiber who is an FRC alum and mentor.

CacheCAD

-Ronnie

4003 switched to Bild last year. It took a little getting used to but overall worked well. Especially like the Checking In/Out files which prevented a lot of errors we had when using GrabCAD. The Online files is also nice, our build team had View Only access to these and could look up the assemblies and drawings to help them understand the design.

We used Bild last year. It worked well for us and improved a lot over the season, its in a pretty good state now, but there is a learning curve.

Note we started on Bild, and were already migrated and locked in before CacheCAD was released, so not trying to dissuade anyone from that option.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-11-21T01:43:54.179Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":20.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470279,"topic_slug":"solidworks-cad-library","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":3321,"username":"Tinsky","name":"Tinsky","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tinsky/{size}/156378_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34415,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design Mentor, Team 2485"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-cad-library/470279/6","custom_user_title":"Design Mentor, Team 2485","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3450385,"name":"Joe Tinnell","username":"jtinnell23","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jtinnell23/{size}/226431_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-21T16:03:31.229Z","cooked":"

We switched to using SolidWorks and 3DExperience at the end of last year. We found the 3DExperience interface is very user-unfriendly, and it’s a steep learning curve. However, once you take the time to learn it, it is an very useful tool. I have two main complaints about it:

  1. As I understand, 3DExperience works by caching files locally on your computer when you open them in SolidWorks from the cloud. My students have gotten into some trouble when they hit CTRL-S to save part files, not knowing that it will simply save the changes to the local cache and not upload them to 3DE. This has created some problems with broken assemblies with missing parts in the cloud. If you use 3DE, you have to get in the habit of hitting the save dropdown menu and clicking “Save to 3DExperience.”
  2. Deleting parts and assemblies can be tedious. You have to open two windows in 3DE (3DSpace and Collaborative Lifecycle), drag the files to be deleted into Collaborative Lifecycle, and delete them. If you don’t have the proper permissions in 3DE, it’ll fail to delete. What’s more, there seems to be a bit of a delay in communication between SolidWorks and 3DE, so if you try to save a part in SolidWorks under a recently-deleted part name in 3DE, it’ll block you. Solution is to just wait a couple minutes.

Despite these challenges, 3DE has been a great tool for us. I’m able to make different Collaborative Spaces for various uses. My favorite of these is our Standard Library. We can put CAD models of all our commonly-used COTS parts, gussets, brackets, etc. in the Standard Library and pull them into assemblies in any other Collaborative Space. Gone are the days of students relocating COTS CAD files locally on the computer to create broken assemblies.

All things considered, 3DE is a great product that I think will serve us well for years to come. We were able to get 25 licenses for $500, and it’s worth every penny in my opinion. Maybe when we get tired of its idiosyncrasies I’ll sick my programming “fixer” on making our own PDM, but we have other priorities for now.
